verse:
एतावानेव लोकेऽस्मिन्पुंसः स्वार्थः परः स्मृतः ।
एकान्तभक्तिर्गोविन्दे यत्सर्वत्र तदीक्षणम् ॥

terms.tat-īkṣaṇam: seeing the relationship with Govinda, Kṛṣṇa.

vedabase.translation: In this material world, to render service to the lotus feet of Govinda, the cause of all causes, and to see Him everywhere, is the only goal of life. This much alone is the ultimate goal of human life, as explained by all the revealed scriptures.
vedabase.purport: In this verse the words sarvatra tad-īkṣaṇam describe the highest perfection of devotional service, in which one sees everything with reference to Govinda’s activities. The highly elevated devotee never sees anything unrelated to Govinda. sthāvara-jaṅgama dekhe, nā dekhe tāra mūrtisarvatra haya nija iṣṭa-deva-sphūrti “The mahā-bhāgavata, the advanced devotee, certainly sees everything mobile and immobile, but he does not exactly see their forms. Rather, everywhere he immediately sees manifest the form of the Supreme Lord.” (Cc. Madhya 8.274) Even in this material world, a devotee does not see materially manifested things; instead he sees Govinda in everything. When he sees a tree or a human being, a devotee sees them in relation to Govinda. Govindam ādi-puruṣam: Govinda is the original source of everything. īśvaraḥ paramaḥ kṛṣṇaḥsac-cid-ānanda-vigrahaḥanādir ādir govindaḥsarva-kāraṇa-kāraṇam “Kṛṣṇa, who is known as Govinda, is the supreme controller. He has an eternal, blissful, spiritual body. He is the origin of all. He has no other origin, for He is the prime cause of all causes.” (Brahma-saṁhitā 5.1) The test of a perfect devotee is that he sees Govinda everywhere in this universe, even in every atomic particle (aṇḍāntara-stha-paramāṇu-cayāntara-stham). This is the perfect vision of a devotee. It is therefore said: nārāyaṇa-mayaṁ dhīrāḥpaśyanti paramārthinaḥjagad dhana-mayaṁ lubdhāḥkāmukāḥ kāminī-mayam A devotee sees everyone and everything in relationship with Nārāyaṇa (nārāyaṇa-mayam). Everything is an expansion of Nārāyaṇa’s energy. Just as those who are greedy see everything as a source of money-making and those who are lusty see everything as being conducive to sex, the most perfect devotee, Prahlāda Mahārāja, saw Nārāyaṇa even within a stone column. This does not mean, however, that we must accept the words daridra-nārāyaṇa, which have been manufactured by some unscrupulous person. One who actually envisions Nārāyaṇa everywhere makes no distinction between the poor and the rich. To single out the daridra-nārāyaṇa, or poor Nārāyaṇa, and reject the dhani-nārāyaṇa, or rich Nārāyaṇa, is not the vision of a devotee. Rather, that is the imperfect vision of materialistic persons. Thus end the Bhaktivedanta purports of the Seventh Canto, Seventh Chapter, of the Śrīmad-Bhāgavatam, entitled “What Prahlāda Learned in the Womb.”

terms.etāvān: so much; eva - indeed; loke - in this world; asmin - this; puṁsaḥ - of a person; svārthaḥ - personal interest; paraḥ - higher; smṛtaḥ - considered; ekānta-bhaktiḥ - exclusive devotion; govinde - to Lord Govinda; yat - which; sarvatra - everywhere; tad - that; īkṣaṇam - vision.

gpt.meaning: The verse emphasizes the importance of developing unwavering devotion towards Lord Govinda, who is recognized as the Supreme Being and the source of all spiritual energy. By directing one's love and devotion towards the Divine, the seeker can break free from the narrow confinement of self centered desires and aspirations. This exclusive devotion enables the individual to perceive the presence of Govinda in every person, object, and experience, leading to a deeper understanding of the interconnectedness and inherent divinity of all creation. In summary, this verse encourages individuals to overcome their self centeredness and cultivate single-minded devotion to Lord Govinda, recognizing His presence everywhere. This shift in perspective allows one to transcend the limitations of personal interests and perceive the divine beauty and harmony that permeates the entire universe.

bard.meaning: That much only in the world is considered to be superior to one's own interest in this person, exclusive devotion to govinda, which is one's vision everywhere.
